publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Paraphrased and Inscribed to IRELAND.
Written in the Year 1725-6.
THE INSCRIPTION.
Poor floating isle, tost on ill fortune's waves, fate to be the land of slaves;Delos now deep-rooted stand;.1O navis, referent in mare te novi_Fluctus.UNHAPPY ship, thou art return'd in vain:
Ordain'd by
Shall moving
Thou, fix'd of old, be now the moving land?
Altho' the metaphor be worn and stale,
Betwixt a state, and vessel under sail;
Let me suppose thee for a ship a-while,
And thus address thee in the sailor's style
New waves shall drive thee to the deep again.
Look to thyself, and be no more the sport2────────Fortiter occupa_Portum: Of giddy winds, but make some friendly port.3Nudum remigio latus. Lost are thy oars, that us'd thy course to guide,
Like faithful counsellors on either side.4────────Malus celeri saucius Africo. Thy mast, which like some aged patriot stood
The single pillar for his country's good,
To lead thee, as a staff directs the blind,
Behold it cracks by yon rough eastern wind.5────────Ac sine funibus_Vix durare carinae_Possint imperiosius_AEquor? Your cables burst, and you must quickly feel
The waves impetuous enter at your keel.
Thus, commonwealths receive a foreign yoke,
When the strong cords of union once are broke,6Non tibi sunt integra lintea. Torn by a sudden tempest is thy sail,
Expanded to invite a milder gale.
As when some writer in a publick cause
His pen to save a sinking nation draws,
While all is calm his arguments prevail;
The people's voice expands his paper sail;
'Till pow'r discharging all her stormy bags
Flutters the feeble pamphlet into rags.
The nation scar'd, the author doom'd to death,
Who fondly put his trust in pop'lar breath.
A larger sacrifice in vain you vow; 7Non Dii, quos interum pressa voces male. There's not a pow'r above will help you now:
A nation thus, who oft heav'n's call neglects,
In vain from injur'd heav'n relief expects.
8Quamvis pontica pinus,_Sylvae filia nobilis.'Twill not avail, when thy strong sides are broke,
That thy descent is from the british oak;
Or, when your name and family you boast,
From fleets triumphant o'er the gallic coast.
Such was Ierne's claim, as just as thine,
Her sons descended from the british line;
Her matchless sons, whose valour still remains
On french records for twenty long campaigns:
Yet, from an empress now a captive grown,
She sav'd Britannia's rights, and lost her own.
9Nil pictis timidus navita puppibus.In ships decay'd no mariner confides,
Lur'd by the gilded stern and painted sides;
Yet at a ball unthinking fools delight
In the gay trappings of a birth-day night:
They on the gold brocades and sattins rav'd,
And quite forgot their country was enslav'd.
10Fidit; tu, nisi ventis_Debes ludibrum, cave.Dear vessel, still be to thy steerage just,
Nor change thy course with ev'ry sudden gust:
Like supple patriots of the modern sort,
Who turn with ev'ry gale that blows from court.
11Nuper solicitum quae mihi taedium,_Nunc desiderium, curaque non levis,_Interfusa nitentes_Vites aequora Cycladas.Weary and sea-sick when in thee confin'd,
Now for thy safety cares distract my mind;
As those, who long have stood the storms of state,
Retire, yet still bemoan their country's fate.
Beware, and when you hear the surges roar,
Avoid the rocks on Britain's angry shore.
They lie, alas! too easy to be found;
For thee alone they lie the island round.770-07H1
